mck-u-animation-slide-down ArticleDefault_mck-c-article-default__heading__bv6rL"><div>Mapping the road to prosperity and parity for Black and Latino residents across America</div></h1></div><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10 mck-u-animation-blur-in-800 ArticleDefault_mck-c-article-default__description__sjoe9"><div><time datetime="2024-03-15T00:00:00Z">March 15, 2024</time> | Article</div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><section data-layer-region="article-body-header" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-animation-blur-in-400 byline-share-container"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-7 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-8 mdc-u-ts-10"></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-animation-blur-in-400"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div class="mck-u-links-inline">Black and Latino US residents experience different levels of prosperity and parity depending on where they live. Our interactive map explores this variation across all US counties.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap"><h4>At a glance</h4>
<ul>
    <li>More than two-thirds of Black and Latino US residents live in the nationâs largest cities, compared to less than half of White residents. While this means some of the issues and barriers facing these two groups are highly concentrated, solutions also can be highly targeted.</li>
    <li>Nowhere do either Black or Latino residents experience even three-quarters the average overall well-being of their White neighbors, although LatinoâWhite disparities are slightly smaller.</li>
    <li>The United States is not on pace to eliminate overall disparities for either Black or Latino residents over the next century.</li>
    <li>The impact of place on prosperity and well-being is profound. Our <a href="#interactivemap">interactive map</a> shows extraordinary variation in both outcome scores and parity on a county-by-county basis.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p><strong>When it comes to measures</strong> of well-being, national averages gloss over the fact that the United States is a vast mosaic of local communities, each with its own story. And within the majority of those communities are sizable disparities between residents of different racial and ethnic backgrounds.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article is a collaborative effort by <a href="/our-people/alberto-chaia">Alberto Chaia</a>, <a href="/our-people/john-paul-julien">JP Julien</a>, <a href="/our-people/lucy-perez">Lucy PÃ©rez</a>, <a href="/our-people/duwain-pinder">Duwain Pinder</a>, <a href="/our-people/shelley-stewart">Shelley Stewart III</a>, Dominic Williams, and Nina Yancy, representing views from McKinseyâs Institute for Black Economic Mobility and the Public and Social Sector Practices.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Our report <a href="/bem/our-insights/the-state-of-black-residents-the-relevance-of-place-to-racial-equity-and-outcomes"><em>The state of Black residents</em></a> analyzed outcomes that Black residents experience across different types of US communities; it also measured the considerable gaps remaining between Black and White neighbors within those places. While the McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility focuses on opportunities and outcomes for Black communities, building a more equitable society requires erasing all racial or ethnic barriers that prevent anyone from reaching their full potential. Here we extend our initial research to examine the experiences of Latino residents across the same metrics. Finally, we offer an interactive map for exploring the overall results for both groups at the county level.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7063eb3a-432c-4245-b1ab-d6bd57320f9f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7063eb3a-432c-4245-b1ab-d6bd57320f9f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Due to limited data availability, we do not assess outcomes for other groups, such as Asian Americans and Native Americans.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>About 19 percent of the US population identifies as Hispanic or Latino, and 13 percent identifies as Black or African American. These are the nationâs two largest racial or ethnic minority groups, and both are remarkably diverse, having descended from dozens of countries and cultures.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5d94ac36-373b-49a7-9bc9-9504de880961"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5d94ac36-373b-49a7-9bc9-9504de880961" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Size of racial and ethnic minority groups based on population estimates from the US Census Bureau as of July 2023. The diversity of Black Americans includes the consideration of whether a Black family traces its roots to enslaved ancestors or to more recent immigrants, although the US Census Bureau does not currently track this.</span></span></span></a></span> For instance, six million adults in the US identify as Afro-Latino (that is, both Black and Hispanic or Latino).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cb6e19b9-a983-41f3-821b-27b9ee7679a0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cb6e19b9-a983-41f3-821b-27b9ee7679a0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ana Gonzalez-Barrera, âAbout 6 million U.S. adults identify as Afro-Latino,â Pew Research Center, May 2, 2022. Notably, about seven million enslaved Africans were transported to what is now Latin America before 1875; by comparison, closer to 400,000 were transported to the United States. See âTrans-Atlantic Slave Trade - Estimates,â SlaveVoyages.</span></span></span></a></span> Roughly two-thirds of the US Latino population was born within the United States, and one-third is foreign born.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b4964379-c6ab-4787-a965-580f2d37e438"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b4964379-c6ab-4787-a965-580f2d37e438" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For an overview, see Jie Zong, <em>A mosaic, not a monolith: A profile of the U.S. Latino population 2000-2020</em>, UCLA Latino Policy & Politics Institute, October 2022; and Mohamad Moslimani and Luis Noe-Bustamente, âFacts on Latinos in the U.S.,â Pew Research Center, August 16, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> For simplicity, this analysis references outcomes for Black, Latino, and non-Hispanic White US residents, although we recognize the complexity underlying these categories.</p>
<p>Previous McKinsey research has highlighted the structural barriers facing Black and Latino households as well as the potential economic impact of their full inclusion.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6f128b89-07ef-40c6-ab0d-d7228016154c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6f128b89-07ef-40c6-ab0d-d7228016154c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See <em><a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-latinos-in-the-us-determined-to-thrive">The economic state of Latinos in the US: Determined to thrive</a></em>, McKinsey, November 2022; <em><a href="/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/the-economic-state-of-latinos-in-america-the-american-dream-deferred">The economic state of Latinos in America: The American dream deferred</a></em>, McKinsey, December 2021; and <em><a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">The economic state of Black America: What is and what could be</a></em>, McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility, June 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Black and Latino communities share some challenges; others may reflect their distinct histories and experiences.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="07f35b2c-c8f9-4ea0-a5b1-1fe464e6ccd2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="07f35b2c-c8f9-4ea0-a5b1-1fe464e6ccd2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For a historical overview of these groupsâ distinct experiences, see, for example, Hugh Davis Graham. âRace, language, and social policy: Comparing the Black and Hispanic experience in the U.S.â <em>Population and Environment</em>, issue 12, number 1, 1990.</span></span></span></a></span> Either way, examining both Black and Latino outcomes reveals the progress the United States could make to ensure that all residents are able to thrive, regardless of race or ethnicity.</p>
<h2>Black and Latino residents are more concentrated in Americaâs large cities than their White peers</h2>
<p>To offer insight into Black and Latino outcomes, we group more than 3,100 US counties into distinct community profiles based on multiple economic and demographic characteristics.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="413b4ebf-99ab-46d3-aa21-342ca707ebde"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="413b4ebf-99ab-46d3-aa21-342ca707ebde" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more details on the community profiles, see <em><a href="/bem/our-insights/the-state-of-black-residents-the-relevance-of-place-to-racial-equity-and-outcomes">The state of Black residents: The relevance of place to racial equity and outcomes</a></em>, McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility, February 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> This article focuses on the eight largest profiles, which account for about 93 percent of both the Black and Latino populations. From most urban to most rural, they are economically dynamic <strong>megacities</strong> (for example, New York, NY; Los Angeles, CA) and <strong>high-growth hubs</strong> (Austin, TX; Charlotte, NC; Minneapolis, MN); the less economically dynamic <strong>stable cities</strong> (Columbus, OH; Detroit, MI; New Orleans, LA) and <strong>independent economies</strong> (Little Rock, AR; Lancaster, PA); more distressed <strong>trailing cities</strong> (Flint, MI; Bridgeport, CT); suburbs and exurbs in the <strong>urban periphery</strong> (San Bernardino, CA; Arlington, VA); and <strong>stable rural counties</strong> and <strong>trailing rural counties</strong>.</p>
<p>More than two-thirds of Black and Latino residents live in the largest urban community profiles (66 and 68 percent, respectively), compared to only 48 percent of White residents in these profiles. In particular, Black and Latino residents are more than twice as likely as White residents to live in megacities, which are home to 30 percent of Black and 38 percent of Latino residents, compared to 15 percent of White residents (Exhibit 1). Black residents are also notably overrepresented in stable cities (home to 19 percent), while Latino residents are slightly overrepresented in both high-growth hubs (9 percent) and trailing cities (7 percent).</p>
<p>An additional 12 to 15 percent of Black and Latino residents live in suburbs and exurbsâcommunities where both groups are underrepresented and White residents are overrepresented. In rural areas, Black residents are twice as likely as White residents to live in trailing rural counties rather than stable rural counties. By contrast, Latino residents are just as likely as White residents to live in stable rural counties (although Latinos are less likely to live in rural areas in the first place).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20institute%20for%20black%20economic%20mobility/our%20insights/mapping%20the%20road%20to%20prosperity%20and%20parity%20for%20black%20and%20latino%20residents%20across%20america/black-and-latino-residents-ex1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Black and Latino residents are concentrated in America's cities." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20institute%20for%20black%20economic%20mobility/our%20insights/mapping%20the%20road%20to%20prosperity%20and%20parity%20for%20black%20and%20latino%20residents%20across%20america/black-and-latino-residents-ex1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Across community profiles, we assess the extent to which both Black and Latino experiences meet a set of aspirations for all US residents, irrespective of race or identity. The aspirations are for all residents to enjoy a basic standard of living; financial stability; job opportunities with decent pay and good working conditions; long and healthy lives; opportunities to develop skills; stable and secure homes; physical and virtual connectivity; and stable communities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8886a7a2-68db-4ae1-b7fd-d98347e3a922"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8886a7a2-68db-4ae1-b7fd-d98347e3a922" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For each aspiration, we use two to four priority metrics. For example, to measure the aspiration for âstable and secure homes,â we assess homeownership rates, rates of overcrowded homes (one or more occupants per room), and share of residents who are rent burdened (spending more than 30 percent of income on rent). For more details on data and methodology, see <em><a href="/bem/our-insights/the-state-of-black-residents-the-relevance-of-place-to-racial-equity-and-outcomes">The state of Black residents: The relevance of place to racial equity and outcomes</a></em>, McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility, February 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>While it is beyond the scope of this article to delve deeply into each topic, we gathered county-level data for 25 hard metrics related to all of these aspirations. Combining them, we produce two scores for each county that reflect general economic, physical, and social well-beingâone absolute and one relative, as follows:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Black or Latino outcome scores:</em> These indicate the level of overall Black or Latino prosperity in a given county relative to that of all Black or Latino residents across the nation, respectively.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e4b57d51-f469-4ae1-8b6a-779013a1bb4e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e4b57d51-f469-4ae1-8b6a-779013a1bb4e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The Black and Latino scores for a given place indicate placement within the distribution of that particular racial or ethnic group only. For example, a Black outcome score that is higher than a Latino outcome score means that Black residents of that place are relatively more prosperous compared to all Black US residents than Latino residents are compared to all Latino US residents. It does not necessarily imply that Black residents of that place are doing better than Latino residents in absolute terms.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>BlackâWhite or LatinoâWhite parity scores:</em> These indicate how far a county is from achieving equivalent outcomes for Black and White residents, or for Latino and White residents, across all metrics.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f0def6cb-3792-4bd2-91b8-8a56a57b31e3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f0def6cb-3792-4bd2-91b8-8a56a57b31e3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">We compare Black and Latino prosperity to White prosperity given that White outcomes are more positive on average; they can serve as a reference point for the level of general well-being that could be possible for Black or Latino residents in a given place.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>
<h2>Nowhere do Black or Latino residents experience even three-quarters the average well-being of their White neighbors, although LatinoâWhite disparities are slightly smaller</h2>
<p>Examining our findings across counties within the same community profiles reveals patterns.</p>
<p>Americaâs <strong>megacities</strong>, where more than one in three Black or Latino US residents live, stand out for having the largest BlackâWhite and LatinoâWhite disparities across all the topics we examine (Exhibit 2). Overall Black outcomes in megacities are only 55 percent of overall White outcomes, on average, and Latino outcomes are 57 percent. This is despite the fact that Black residents of megacities are comparatively better off than their peers in many other community profiles, with positive job and education outcomes (albeit offset by high costs of living, widespread rent burdens, and long commutes). By contrast, megacities produce some of the lowest overall Latino outcomes in the nation (Exhibit 3). Initiatives in Americaâs largest cities could be best positioned to lift up the greatest numbers of struggling Latino residents, while also helping to address sizable BlackâWhite disparities.</p>
<p>The <strong>urban periphery</strong> stands out for having the best balance of overall outcomes and parity for Black and Latino residents alike, although both groups are underrepresented in the suburbs and exurbs. They see similar levels of parity with White residents: overall Black and Latino outcomes are both about 64 percent of White outcomes across the topics we analyze. For Black residents, this level of parity reflects notably greater prosperity in the urban periphery than in other community profiles, whereas Latino prosperity in the urban periphery is not as exceptional. In other words, the urban periphery offers Black residents a distinctly more positive experience than Black Americans find elsewhere, while Latino experiences in the suburbs and exurbs are slightly better than elsewhere but not markedly so.</p>

If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The other <strong>urban community</strong> profilesâhigh-growth hubs, independent economies, stable cities, and trailing citiesâhave relatively similar degrees of LatinoâWhite parity, with Latino outcomes between 61 and 63 percent of White well-being. Overall, their levels of Latino prosperity reflect their underlying economies, with outcomes that are better in high-growth hubs and worse in trailing cities. By contrast, there is more variation in Black resident experiences across these urban areas. Most notably, Black prosperity is significantly lower in stable cities and trailing cities. Stable cities, where Black residents are overrepresented, have the nationâs largest overall BlackâWhite gaps.</p>
<p>Last, we consider the two <strong>rural community</strong> profiles. Trailing rural counties see the greatest parity for both Black and Latino residents (Black outcomes are about 69 percent and Latino outcomes about 72 percent of White outcomes). But these communities also have the nationâs lowest overall outcomes for both groups. In other words, higher parity reflects poor outcomes for White residents as well. In stable rural counties, a similar pattern holds for Black residents, while Latino residents do somewhat better on both prosperity and parity.</p>
<p>Beyond these variations across community profiles is a stark reality: In none of them do either Black or Latino residents experience even three-quarters of their White neighborsâ overall level of economic, physical, and social well-being. Black outcomes range from 55 to 69 percent of White outcomes, on average, across community profiles, whereas the range for Latino outcomes is 57 to 72 percent. Overall, LatinoâWhite gaps are slightly smaller, yet still significant. Inequity is ever-present in multiple aspects of life for both of the nationâs largest minority groups.</p>
<h2>The nation is not on pace to erase racial and ethnic disparities in our lifetimes, although the gaps facing Latinos could close sooner</h2>
<p>To assess whether conditions are at least moving in the right direction, we looked at changes over the past decade for Black and Latino residents.</p>
<p>Between 2012 and 2021, overall outcomes improved for both groups in most US counties; the good news is that their overall economic, physical, and social well-being was higher at the decadeâs end than at the start (Exhibit 4). Yet in many places, outcomes for White residents improved to the same degree or even more, meaning that gaps never closed. While this trend holds for both groups, Latino progress was somewhat more geographically distributed, with outcomes improving in 86 percent of all US counties (compared to 73 percent of counties showing progress for Black residents). And while LatinoâWhite disparities shrank in two-thirds of US counties over the decade, fewer than half saw reduced BlackâWhite disparities.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20institute%20for%20black%20economic%20mobility/our%20insights/mapping%20the%20road%20to%20prosperity%20and%20parity%20for%20black%20and%20latino%20residents%20across%20america/black-and-latino-residents-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Outcomes for Black and Latino residents are improving across most US counties, but progress toward parity has been harder to achieve." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20institute%20for%20black%20economic%20mobility/our%20insights/mapping%20the%20road%20to%20prosperity%20and%20parity%20for%20black%20and%20latino%20residents%20across%20america/black-and-latino-residents-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>In light of these recent trends, the outlooks for Black and Latino residents are meaningfully different (Exhibit 5). Based on the rate of change between 2012 and 2021, the gaps in outcomes between Latino residents and their White neighbors are on track to close centuries sooner than those separating Black and White residents. The pace of progress toward parity varies across different places as well. Looking across the different community profiles, it could take anywhere from 70 to 120 years to close LatinoâWhite gaps on average. But the comparable number for closing BlackâWhite gaps is 120 to 320 years.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20institute%20for%20black%20economic%20mobility/our%20insights/mapping%20the%20road%20to%20prosperity%20and%20parity%20for%20black%20and%20latino%20residents%20across%20america/black-and-latino-residents-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="At the current pace, it could take upto 120 years to close overall Latino-White gaps and upto 320 years to close Black-White gaps." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20institute%20for%20black%20economic%20mobility/our%20insights/mapping%20the%20road%20to%20prosperity%20and%20parity%20for%20black%20and%20latino%20residents%20across%20america/black-and-latino-residents-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Our finding that Latino residents are making relatively faster progress toward parity than their Black counterparts is consistent with other research.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7ac4d5ed-4a94-4286-bc83-0c4151b24d11"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7ac4d5ed-4a94-4286-bc83-0c4151b24d11" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See, for example, Tim Henderson, âHispanic families continue to climb to middle class,â <em>Governing</em>, December 2023. These findings are counterbalanced, however, by both the precarity of many Latino (or Black) familiesâ position in the middle class, and the stagnation Latinos in the US have experienced in other areas. See Rakesh Kochhar and Stella Sechopoulos, âBlack and Hispanic Americans, those with less education are more likely to fall out of the middle class each year,â Pew Research Center, May 10, 2022; and Marie T. Mora and Alberto Davila, <em>The Hispanicâwhite wage gap has remained wide and relatively steady</em>, Economic Policy Institute, July 2018;. In addition, economic outcomes for foreign-born Latinos are often less positive than those of US-born Latinos; see <em><a href="/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/the-economic-state-of-latinos-in-america-the-american-dream-deferred">The economic state of Latinos in America: The American dream deferred</a></em>, McKinsey, December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> For example, McKinsey research found that Latino enrollment is helping to drive the shift toward greater representation of students of color at US colleges and universities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="34bb23d4-70f4-48d0-8e20-14cf3abf4a47"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="34bb23d4-70f4-48d0-8e20-14cf3abf4a47" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/industries/education/our-insights/racial-and-ethnic-equity-in-us-higher-education">Racial and ethnic equity in US higher education</a></em>, McKinsey, July 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Latinos also are more likely than Black residents to have personal or family histories of immigration, and it is well established that the children of immigrants experience higher upward mobility than US-born children.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6b9bdb88-c58b-48ff-ac81-020f012fbe2d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6b9bdb88-c58b-48ff-ac81-020f012fbe2d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">On the upward mobility of immigrants (and their children), see, for example, Ran Abramitzky et al., âIntergenerational mobility of immigrants in the United States over two centuries,â <em>American Economic Review</em>, volume 111, number 2, February 2021. On the comparison between immigrant experiences and those of Black Americans with enslaved ancestors, see William Darity, âWhatâs left of the economic theory of discrimination?â in <em>The question of discrimination: Racial inequality in the U.S. labor market</em>, Steven Shulman and William Darity Jr., eds., Wesleyan University Press, 1989.</span></span></span></a></span> As a result of these trends, a child born today might live to see LatinoâWhite disparitiesâbut not BlackâWhite disparitiesâclosed across some community profiles.</p>
<p>Despite these differences, it is still taking too long to achieve parity for both groups, raising the risk that racial and ethnic gaps could continue to be a generational challenge. Moreover, this analysis holds White outcomes constant for simplicity, even though history indicates they are likely to continue improving.</p>
<p>Dramatically accelerating the timeline to parity for both Black and Latino residents would mean upending the status quo. It is not easy to address all the factors at play; our parity scores reflect gaps in jobs and educational opportunities, housing, healthcare, and self-reported physical and mental well-being, among other topics. Our previously published <a href="/bem/our-insights/the-state-of-black-residents-the-relevance-of-place-to-racial-equity-and-outcomes">research</a> on Black residents explored two potential initiatives in greater detail: affordable housing and high-quality universal public preschool. These efforts would similarly benefit Latino communitiesâand, indeed, residents of all backgrounds. While they require substantial investment, they could also yield real long-term social and economic returns.</p>
<h2>Explore the data in detail</h2>
<p>The aggregated community profiles discussed earlier offer a way to understand the experiences of Black and Latino residents, but even this segmentation does not capture the remarkable variation that exists from place to place.</p>
<p>We therefore invite readers to explore our data in greater detail using the interactive map below. Clicking on the âCommunity profileâ tab shows each countyâs classification, while the other tabs offer views based on demographics and our calculated outcome and parity scores. Users can also hover directly over any US county to see its statistics.</p>
<a id="interactivemap"></a>

<hr>
<p>Our research takes a place-based view on the theory that many of the issues holding back progress for racial and ethnic minority groups are influenced by local conditions, and some of the solutions may be best designed and delivered at the local level. This view highlights where the need is greatestâand where action from the public, private, and social sectors can help to narrow the gaps.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/alberto-chaia">Alberto Chaia</a></strong> is a senior partner in McKinsey<span style="line-height: 110%;">â</span>s Miami office, <strong><a href="/our-people/john-paul-julien">JP Julien</a></strong> is a partner in the Philadelphia office, <strong><a href="/our-people/lucy-perez">Lucy PÃ©rez</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Boston office, and <strong><a href="/our-people/duwain-pinder">Duwain Pinder</a></strong> is a partner in the Columbus, OH, office. <strong><a href="/our-people/shelley-stewart">Shelley Stewart III</a></strong> is a senior partner who leads the McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility and is based in the New York office, where <strong>Dominic Williams</strong> is an associate partner and <strong>Nina Yancy</strong> is an engagement manager.</p>

<i>MGI Research</i></span><h6 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-6"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be" class="mdc-c-link-heading___Zggl8_990311c mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c"><div>The economic state of Black America: What is and what could be</div></a></h6></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></main><div class="mck-u-sr-only" role="log" aria-live="polite" aria-relevant="additions" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Mapping the road to prosperity and parity for Black and Latino residents across America","displayName":"Mapping the road to prosperity and parity for Black and Latino residents across America","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"d9774fd1-feab-4066-bc5d-ea197d7755a5","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Mapping the road to prosperity and parity for Black and Latino residents across America"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Mapping inequality for Black and Latino residents"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Black and Latino US residents experience different levels of prosperity and parity depending on where they live. Our interactive map explores this variation across all US counties."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Black and Latino Americans experience different levels of prosperity and parity depending on where they live. Our interactive mapping explores this inequality."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-03-15T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"\u003ch4\u003eAt a glance\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMore than two-thirds of Black and Latino US residents live in the nation\u0026rsquo;s largest cities, compared to less than half of White residents. While this means some of the issues and barriers facing these two groups are highly concentrated, solutions also can be highly targeted.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eNowhere do either Black or Latino residents experience even three-quarters the average overall well-being of their White neighbors, although Latino\u0026ndash;White disparities are slightly smaller.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe United States is not on pace to eliminate overall disparities for either Black or Latino residents over the next century.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe impact of place on prosperity and well-being is profound. Our \u003ca href=\"#interactivemap\"\u003einteractive map\u003c/a\u003e shows extraordinary variation in both outcome scores and parity on a county-by-county basis.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen it comes to measures\u003c/strong\u003e of well-being, national averages gloss over the fact that the United States is a vast mosaic of local communities, each with its own story. And within the majority of those communities are sizable disparities between residents of different racial and ethnic backgrounds.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar Authors]]\n\u003cp\u003eOur report \u003ca href=\"/bem/our-insights/the-state-of-black-residents-the-relevance-of-place-to-racial-equity-and-outcomes\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe state of Black residents\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;analyzed outcomes that Black residents experience across different types of US communities; it also measured the considerable gaps remaining between Black and White neighbors within those places. While the McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility focuses on opportunities and outcomes for Black communities, building a more equitable society requires erasing all racial or ethnic barriers that prevent anyone from reaching their full potential. Here we extend our initial research to examine the experiences of Latino residents across the same metrics. Finally, we offer an interactive map for exploring the overall results for both groups at the county level.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAbout 19 percent of the US population identifies as Hispanic or Latino, and 13 percent identifies as Black or African American. These are the nation\u0026rsquo;s two largest racial or ethnic minority groups, and both are remarkably diverse, having descended from dozens of countries and cultures.[[footnote 2]] For instance, six million adults in the US identify as Afro-Latino (that is, both Black and Hispanic or Latino).[[footnote 3]] Roughly two-thirds of the US Latino population was born within the United States, and one-third is foreign born.[[footnote 4]] For simplicity, this analysis references outcomes for Black, Latino, and non-Hispanic White US residents, although we recognize the complexity underlying these categories.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePrevious McKinsey research has highlighted the structural barriers facing Black and Latino households as well as the potential economic impact of their full inclusion.[[footnote 5]] Black and Latino communities share some challenges; others may reflect their distinct histories and experiences.[[footnote 6]] Either way, examining both Black and Latino outcomes reveals the progress the United States could make to ensure that all residents are able to thrive, regardless of race or ethnicity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eBlack and Latino residents are more concentrated in America\u0026rsquo;s large cities than their White peers\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo offer insight into Black and Latino outcomes, we group more than 3,100 US counties into distinct community profiles based on multiple economic and demographic characteristics.[[footnote 7]] This article focuses on the eight largest profiles, which account for about 93 percent of both the Black and Latino populations. From most urban to most rural, they are economically dynamic \u003cstrong\u003emegacities\u003c/strong\u003e (for example, New York, NY; Los Angeles, CA) and \u003cstrong\u003ehigh-growth hubs\u003c/strong\u003e (Austin, TX; Charlotte, NC; Minneapolis, MN); the less economically dynamic \u003cstrong\u003estable cities\u003c/strong\u003e (Columbus, OH; Detroit, MI; New Orleans, LA) and \u003cstrong\u003eindependent economies\u003c/strong\u003e (Little Rock, AR; Lancaster, PA); more distressed \u003cstrong\u003etrailing cities\u003c/strong\u003e (Flint, MI; Bridgeport, CT); suburbs and exurbs in the \u003cstrong\u003eurban periphery\u003c/strong\u003e (San Bernardino, CA; Arlington, VA); and \u003cstrong\u003estable rural counties\u003c/strong\u003e and \u003cstrong\u003etrailing rural counties\u003c/strong\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore than two-thirds of Black and Latino residents live in the largest urban community profiles (66 and 68 percent, respectively), compared to only 48 percent of White residents in these profiles. In particular, Black and Latino residents are more than twice as likely as White residents to live in megacities, which are home to 30 percent of Black and 38 percent of Latino residents, compared to 15 percent of White residents (Exhibit 1). Black residents are also notably overrepresented in stable cities (home to 19 percent), while Latino residents are slightly overrepresented in both high-growth hubs (9 percent) and trailing cities (7 percent).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn additional 12 to 15 percent of Black and Latino residents live in suburbs and exurbs\u0026mdash;communities where both groups are underrepresented and White residents are overrepresented. In rural areas, Black residents are twice as likely as White residents to live in trailing rural counties rather than stable rural counties. By contrast, Latino residents are just as likely as White residents to live in stable rural counties (although Latinos are less likely to live in rural areas in the first place).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAcross community profiles, we assess the extent to which both Black and Latino experiences meet a set of aspirations for all US residents, irrespective of race or identity. The aspirations are for all residents to enjoy a basic standard of living; financial stability; job opportunities with decent pay and good working conditions; long and healthy lives; opportunities to develop skills; stable and secure homes; physical and virtual connectivity; and stable communities.[[footnote 8]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile it is beyond the scope of this article to delve deeply into each topic, we gathered county-level data for 25 hard metrics related to all of these aspirations. Combining them, we produce two scores for each county that reflect general economic, physical, and social well-being\u0026mdash;one absolute and one relative, as follows:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBlack or Latino outcome scores:\u003c/em\u003e These indicate the level of overall Black or Latino prosperity in a given county relative to that of all Black or Latino residents across the nation, respectively.[[footnote 9]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBlack\u0026ndash;White or Latino\u0026ndash;White parity scores:\u003c/em\u003e These indicate how far a county is from achieving equivalent outcomes for Black and White residents, or for Latino and White residents, across all metrics.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eNowhere do Black or Latino residents experience even three-quarters the average well-being of their White neighbors, although Latino\u0026ndash;White disparities are slightly smaller\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExamining our findings across counties within the same community profiles reveals patterns.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmerica\u0026rsquo;s \u003cstrong\u003emegacities\u003c/strong\u003e, where more than one in three Black or Latino US residents live, stand out for having the largest Black\u0026ndash;White and Latino\u0026ndash;White disparities across all the topics we examine (Exhibit 2). Overall Black outcomes in megacities are only 55 percent of overall White outcomes, on average, and Latino outcomes are 57 percent. This is despite the fact that Black residents of megacities are comparatively better off than their peers in many other community profiles, with positive job and education outcomes (albeit offset by high costs of living, widespread rent burdens, and long commutes). By contrast, megacities produce some of the lowest overall Latino outcomes in the nation (Exhibit 3). Initiatives in America\u0026rsquo;s largest cities could be best positioned to lift up the greatest numbers of struggling Latino residents, while also helping to address sizable Black\u0026ndash;White disparities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003cstrong\u003eurban periphery\u003c/strong\u003e stands out for having the best balance of overall outcomes and parity for Black and Latino residents alike, although both groups are underrepresented in the suburbs and exurbs. They see similar levels of parity with White residents: overall Black and Latino outcomes are both about 64 percent of White outcomes across the topics we analyze. For Black residents, this level of parity reflects notably greater prosperity in the urban periphery than in other community profiles, whereas Latino prosperity in the urban periphery is not as exceptional. In other words, the urban periphery offers Black residents a distinctly more positive experience than Black Americans find elsewhere, while Latino experiences in the suburbs and exurbs are slightly better than elsewhere but not markedly so.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe other \u003cstrong\u003eurban community\u003c/strong\u003e profiles\u0026mdash;high-growth hubs, independent economies, stable cities, and trailing cities\u0026mdash;have relatively similar degrees of Latino\u0026ndash;White parity, with Latino outcomes between 61 and 63 percent of White well-being. Overall, their levels of Latino prosperity reflect their underlying economies, with outcomes that are better in high-growth hubs and worse in trailing cities. By contrast, there is more variation in Black resident experiences across these urban areas. Most notably, Black prosperity is significantly lower in stable cities and trailing cities. Stable cities, where Black residents are overrepresented, have the nation\u0026rsquo;s largest overall Black\u0026ndash;White gaps.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLast, we consider the two \u003cstrong\u003erural community\u003c/strong\u003e profiles. Trailing rural counties see the greatest parity for both Black and Latino residents (Black outcomes are about 69 percent and Latino outcomes about 72 percent of White outcomes). But these communities also have the nation\u0026rsquo;s lowest overall outcomes for both groups. In other words, higher parity reflects poor outcomes for White residents as well. In stable rural counties, a similar pattern holds for Black residents, while Latino residents do somewhat better on both prosperity and parity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBeyond these variations across community profiles is a stark reality: In none of them do either Black or Latino residents experience even three-quarters of their White neighbors\u0026rsquo; overall level of economic, physical, and social well-being. Black outcomes range from 55 to 69 percent of White outcomes, on average, across community profiles, whereas the range for Latino outcomes is 57 to 72 percent. Overall, Latino\u0026ndash;White gaps are slightly smaller, yet still significant. Inequity is ever-present in multiple aspects of life for both of the nation\u0026rsquo;s largest minority groups.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe nation is not on pace to erase racial and ethnic disparities in our lifetimes, although the gaps facing Latinos could close sooner\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo assess whether conditions are at least moving in the right direction, we looked at changes over the past decade for Black and Latino residents.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBetween 2012 and 2021, overall outcomes improved for both groups in most US counties; the good news is that their overall economic, physical, and social well-being was higher at the decade\u0026rsquo;s end than at the start (Exhibit 4). Yet in many places, outcomes for White residents improved to the same degree or even more, meaning that gaps never closed. While this trend holds for both groups, Latino progress was somewhat more geographically distributed, with outcomes improving in 86 percent of all US counties (compared to 73 percent of counties showing progress for Black residents). And while Latino\u0026ndash;White disparities shrank in two-thirds of US counties over the decade, fewer than half saw reduced Black\u0026ndash;White disparities.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn light of these recent trends, the outlooks for Black and Latino residents are meaningfully different (Exhibit 5). Based on the rate of change between 2012 and 2021, the gaps in outcomes between Latino residents and their White neighbors are on track to close centuries sooner than those separating Black and White residents. The pace of progress toward parity varies across different places as well. Looking across the different community profiles, it could take anywhere from 70 to 120 years to close Latino\u0026ndash;White gaps on average. But the comparable number for closing Black\u0026ndash;White gaps is 120 to 320 years.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eOur finding that Latino residents are making relatively faster progress toward parity than their Black counterparts is consistent with other research.[[footnote 11]] For example, McKinsey research found that Latino enrollment is helping to drive the shift toward greater representation of students of color at US colleges and universities.[[footnote 12]] Latinos also are more likely than Black residents to have personal or family histories of immigration, and it is well established that the children of immigrants experience higher upward mobility than US-born children.[[footnote 13]] As a result of these trends, a child born today might live to see Latino\u0026ndash;White disparities\u0026mdash;but not Black\u0026ndash;White disparities\u0026mdash;closed across some community profiles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite these differences, it is still taking too long to achieve parity for both groups, raising the risk that racial and ethnic gaps could continue to be a generational challenge. Moreover, this analysis holds White outcomes constant for simplicity, even though history indicates they are likely to continue improving.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDramatically accelerating the timeline to parity for both Black and Latino residents would mean upending the status quo. It is not easy to address all the factors at play; our parity scores reflect gaps in jobs and educational opportunities, housing, healthcare, and self-reported physical and mental well-being, among other topics. Our previously published \u003ca href=\"/bem/our-insights/the-state-of-black-residents-the-relevance-of-place-to-racial-equity-and-outcomes\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on Black residents explored two potential initiatives in greater detail: affordable housing and high-quality universal public preschool. These efforts would similarly benefit Latino communities\u0026mdash;and, indeed, residents of all backgrounds. While they require substantial investment, they could also yield real long-term social and economic returns.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eExplore the data in detail\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe aggregated community profiles discussed earlier offer a way to understand the experiences of Black and Latino residents, but even this segmentation does not capture the remarkable variation that exists from place to place.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe therefore invite readers to explore our data in greater detail using the interactive map below. Clicking on the \u0026ldquo;Community profile\u0026rdquo; tab shows each county\u0026rsquo;s classification, while the other tabs offer views based on demographics and our calculated outcome and parity scores. Users can also hover directly over any US county to see its statistics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca id=\"interactivemap\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n[[Exhibit 6]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur research takes a place-based view on the theory that many of the issues holding back progress for racial and ethnic minority groups are influenced by local conditions, and some of the solutions may be best designed and delivered at the local level. This view highlights where the need is greatest\u0026mdash;and where action from the public, private, and social sectors can help to narrow the gaps.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":true},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":{"name":"McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility","displayName":"McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility","title":{"value":"McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility"},"relatedlinks":{"url":"/bem/overview"},"landinglinks":{"jsonValue":{"value":[]}}}},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":false},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-03-15T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDue to limited data availability, we do not assess outcomes for other groups, such as Asian Americans and Native Americans.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSize of racial and ethnic minority groups based on population estimates from the US Census Bureau as of July 2023. For example, to measure the aspiration for \u0026ldquo;stable and secure homes,\u0026rdquo; we assess homeownership rates, rates of overcrowded homes (one or more occupants per room), and share of residents who are rent burdened (spending more than 30 percent of income on rent). For more details on data and methodology, see \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/bem/our-insights/the-state-of-black-residents-the-relevance-of-place-to-racial-equity-and-outcomes\"\u003eThe state of Black residents: The relevance of place to racial equity and outcomes\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility, February 2024.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe Black and Latino scores for a given place indicate placement within the distribution of that particular racial or ethnic group only. For example, a Black outcome score that is higher than a Latino outcome score means that Black residents of that place are relatively more prosperous compared to all Black US residents than Latino residents are compared to all Latino US residents. It does not necessarily imply that Black residents of that place are doing better than Latino residents in absolute terms.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eWe compare Black and Latino prosperity to White prosperity given that White outcomes are more positive on average; they can serve as a reference point for the level of general well-being that could be possible for Black or Latino residents in a given place.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSee, for example, Tim Henderson, \u0026ldquo;Hispanic families continue to climb to middle class,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eGoverning\u003c/em\u003e, December 2023.
